Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Multihop Multiflow Wireless Networks: A Treasure Hunt

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wireless networks are the dominant medium through which people connect to the Internet, communicate, do business and access information. The ever-growing demand for higher data rates places the conventional approaches to network design under considerable stress. To meet this demand, future wireless networks are rapidly evolving towards high-density, user-deployed, heterogeneous infrastructure characterized by very high data rates at shorter communication range, with possibly harsh interference. In this context, multiple flow and multiple hop communication is expected to play an increasingly important role. Yet, current visions of how such networks should be designed are limited by the fact that the fundamental understanding of such novel communication paradigms is still in its infancy.

This research addresses key questions about multihop multiflow networks in the form of new ideas, insights and tools, with a transformative impact on the design of future networks. The project is organized into three symbiotic research thrusts on extensibility, side information and algorithms. In the extensibility thrust, the investigators develop a new understanding of the capacity of multihop multiflow networks of prototypical network models. The side information thrust moves beyond idealized model assumptions and incorporates imperfect or uncertain conditions at multiple spatial and temporal scales. The third thrust on algorithms translates the new key ideas developed in the first two thrusts into explicit coding and signal processing algorithms with polynomial complexity in the network size, for resource-efficient multiflow multihop communication. The research can broadly impact the wireless industry by generating new ideas that will power the design of future generations of wireless networks. The project also includes a dedicated educational plan to recruit and train under-represented minorities in this field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wireless multihop multiflow networks are expected to play a key role in bridging the digital divide and providing broadband to rural areas in developing nations, open doors to trillions of dollars of e-commerce, provide vast amounts of easily accessible knowledge to the public, dramatically reduce operational costs to increase efficiency of most organizations, and potentially save lives by providing much needed emergency communications in the wake of natural (or man-made) disasters. The fundamentals of multihop multiflow wireless networks represent an increasingly relevant, enormous in scope, and largely unexplored problem space where, for the most part, even first order capacity approximations were not available. Exploring this rich space in the manner of a treasure hunt, in this project we found new characterizations of fundamental limits and elegant descriptions of broad regimes where robust solutions are optimal. For new fundamental limits we found various ways to incoporate the structure of a network in terms of rank-deficiencies of network submatrices and characterize how these structural constraints fundamentally impact the ability of the network to carry information. Our results characterize the degrees of freedom (signaling dimensions) available under rank-deficiencies in network submatrices, and may be viewed as generalizations of the min-cut bound that is the staple of network information theory. In the direction of robust solutions, we characterized a broad regime where the simple scheme of treating interference as noise is approximately optimal in the information theoretic sense. The result extends to arbitrary number of users, asymmetric signal settings, general message sets, with or without secrecy constraints. In spite of the number of parameters, the results provide an elegant characterization of the approximate capacity by implicitly optimizing and eliminating power control variables based on novel applications of  powerful results from combinatorial optimization. The outcomes of this project include highly cited works presented at the top IEEE journals and conferences in the fields of information and communication theory, and have  inspired much follow up work, e.g.,  on approximately optimal power control algorithms, and information-theoretic scheduling strategies. Several graduate students were trained through their participation in this project and went on to secure positions in industry and research labs.
